overview: In this subject students consolidate the basic elements covered in Latin 1, and are introduced to more complex grammar and syntax. Increasingly difficult literary and dramatic texts are read. Background information on Roman culture is woven into the subject matter throughout the semester. By the end of the subject, students should have a sufficient grasp of the language to read texts of moderate difficulty with vocabulary assistance. Students who complete this subject may progress to Latin 3.
ilo: Read and comprehend basic Latin texts
Translate basic Latin passages and sentences into English
Identify and explain basic Latin grammar, vocabulary and syntax
Identify and articulate the relationship between basic Latin texts and their original socio-cultural context.

content.Name: Latin 1
content.Teaching period: Semester 1 (On Campus - Parkville)Summer Term (On Campus - Parkville)

Non-allowed subjects.content: Students who have completed VCE Latin are not permitted to enrol in this subject.

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.hurdle: 1. Attendance hurdle requirement: This subject has a minimum requirement of 80% attendance at tutorials, seminars, or workshops. There is an expectation that students attend lectures.

2. Late Penalty and Assessment hurdle requirement: Assessment submitted late without an approved extension will be penalised at five per cent (5%) of the possible marks available for the assessment task per day or part thereof. All pieces of assessment must be submitted to pass the subject. Each submitted assessment must be complete, constitute a genuine attempt to address the requirements of the task and will not be accepted after 20 University business days from the original assessment due date without written approval.

date_times.contact_hours: Summer - 45 hours: 1 hour lecture and 2 hours of tutorials per day for 15 days.
Semester 2 - 48 hours: 1 hour lecture per week for 12 weeks and 1 hour tutorial 3 times per week for 12 weeks.
